Ganz.Action: Grins and jokes with guard Brady, showing a friendly rapport.
Mocks Billy Bear with racial slurs and insults, provoking a fight.
Leans on his hoe and makes sarcastic remarks to Billy Bear, provoking a fight.
Shoots Brady at point-blank range during escape attempt.
Smiles while firing pistol during escape.
Commands others to come on and escape together.
Successfully shoots Brady at point-blank range and fires at the second guard, enabling escape.
Fires twice at a distant target but misses due to range limitations.
Quickly escapes with Billy by driving a pickup onto a semi-truck and then fleeing in a station wagon.
Smiles and says 'You know something? I'm having a real good time.' after a tense moment.
Dives for the floor as police cars go by, then reappears smiling and says he's having a good time.
Snorts derisively at Henry's joke about credit cards not being 'room temperature.'
Pockets stolen credit cards without hesitation.
Suggests buying prostitutes after dealing with Henry.
Inspects credit cards carefully and questions their validity, showing awareness and control of the situation.
Takes the credit cards and plans to follow Henry slowly, indicating strategic thinking and caution.
Asks to drive and suggests buying pros after dealing with Henry, showing confidence and planning.
Engages in casual banter with Billy, explaining 'pros' and money, showing clear communication and leadership.
Encourages Billy to trust him and promises to pay for the girls to have a good time.
Insists Billy should just do what he says without much explanation.
Insists on paying for the girls to ensure they can do anything, showing understanding of how to negotiate and control the situation.
Tells Billy to just do what he says and asks for trust, demonstrating leadership and confidence.
Pulls a gun on Luther and threatens Rosalie, showing willingness to use violence to get money.
Says 'I always liked you, Luther. You were always a lotta fun to hang out with,' showing some personal fondness despite the threat.
Surprises Luther by ambushing him and Rosalie, showing initiative and control of the situation.
Uses intimidation effectively by threatening Luther and Rosalie to get information.
Demonstrates patience and strategic thinking by not killing Rosalie immediately and instead using her as leverage.
Relinquishes the gun after Luther promises the money on Monday, showing some trust but also calculated risk.
Keeps Rosalie as a hostage to maintain leverage, indicating tactical awareness.
Threatens violence against Rosalie if she goes to the cops.
Smiles and pinches Luther on the cheek before shoving him out of the car.
Gives Rosalie a casual smile and threatens to cut her throat.
Interacts casually and somewhat friendly with the hotel clerk.
Makes demeaning and objectifying comments about the type of woman he wants for a room.
Threatens violence to maintain control and intimidate others, shows confidence in handling the situation.
Pins Luther on the cheek and shoves him out of the car, demonstrating dominance and control.
Casually smiles and makes a threatening comment to Rosalie, showing calmness under pressure.
Successfully rents hotel rooms without raising suspicion, handles the interaction smoothly.
Focuses on specific details for the girl (appearance, dress) indicating planning and attention to detail.
Takes the photograph of the dead man and slips it into his jacket pocket, showing a practical and somewhat detached behavior.
Makes a culturally insensitive comment referring to an 'Indian' and 'squaw' when asking for a Polaroid, showing a lack of respect and tolerance.
Gives Frizzy a sharp look and tells her to keep her 'filthy ideas' to herself, indicating impatience and brusqueness rather than friendliness or tolerance.
Takes the photograph of the dead man and carefully slips it into his jacket pocket, indicating awareness and caution.
Uses hot credit cards with an alias to arrange a hotel room, showing planning and resourcefulness.
Gives a sharp look to Frizzy to shut down her suggestive comment, demonstrating control and confidence.
Reacts instantly and draws an automatic weapon upon hearing knocks at the door, showing alertness and readiness.
Shoves the gun into Lisa's stomach, potentially indicating aggression or poor judgment in handling the situation.
Shoves Lisa hard with a pistol and orders her to be silent and to stall the police.
Smiles almost enjoying the moment of intimidation and control over Lisa.
Commands Lisa to stall the police and maintains control of the situation with confidence, showing tactical awareness.
Uses intimidation effectively by shoving Lisa with a pistol to enforce compliance.
Smiles almost enjoying the moment, indicating calmness under pressure.
Belts Lisa with his gun to incapacitate her and slips into the adjacent room, showing decisiveness and quick action.
Commands Algren to drop his gun to save Rosalie, negotiates to avoid immediate violence.
Smiles after picking up the gun, shows a moment of calm control.
Threatens to kill Cates despite the negotiation, indicating ruthless intent.
Commands Algren to drop his gun and then orders Cates to do the same, successfully de-escalating the immediate threat and gaining control of the situation.
Picks up the gun and smiles confidently, showing control and readiness to act.
Issues clear, direct orders under pressure, demonstrating leadership and tactical awareness.
Shoots Algren twice, killing him; strikes Frizzy across the head causing her to slump.
Smiles after killing Algren and taunts Cates by using his own gun.
Leisurely shoots at Cates hiding in the phone booth, showing no remorse.
Shoots Algren twice with Cates' gun, killing him quickly and decisively.
Swipes Frizzy across the head to subdue her effectively.
Uses Cates' own gun against him, demonstrating tactical awareness and psychological advantage.
Leisurely shoots at the phone booth where Cates hides, showing confidence and control of the situation.
Retreats when police sirens approach, avoiding capture.
Smiles after killing Algren and taunts Cates, indicating possible overconfidence or arrogance.
Broke out of prison two days ago and killed two guards during the escape.
Known as a 'hitter' with a criminal background, implying skill and experience in violent crime.

Busted out of jail with a big Indian, killed two guards on a road gang.

Is the subject of a search and interrogation but does not appear directly in the excerpt; Luther claims not to have seen him for years, possibly indicating Ganz's ability to stay hidden or avoid detection.
Is implicated in kidnapping Luther's girl, Rosalie, suggesting involvement in criminal or risky activity that may reflect poor judgment or recklessness.
Is the target of a bet involving obtaining his phone number or killing him, indicating he is a key figure in a complex situation.

Is referred to as a 'charcoal-colored loser' and a 'turd' by Cates, indicating low regard for his capability.
Is the target of Hammond's offer to handle him alone, implying Ganz is a significant threat or challenge.
Is mentioned as a threat to take Hammond's money, implying he is a capable adversary.
Is expected to arrive on time to take over the stakeout, indicating reliability and responsibility.
Is assumed by Hammond to be incapacitated or 'put down for a long time,' suggesting possible doubts about Ganz's current effectiveness or presence.
Motions Luther to move away to avoid confrontation.
Fires a gun wildly into the ceiling, causing panic among bystanders.
Runs away through the crowd with accomplices after shooting.
Moves cautiously through the station, scanning faces to locate Luther.
Fails to notice Cates and Hammond closing in on him from two directions.
Reacts quickly to the threat by making an immediate break for open ground.
Swings Cates' .44 toward Hammond but misses, shooting into the ceiling instead.
Scrambles through the crowd to escape after the Patrolman draws his gun.
Elbows and kicks through the crowd, tugs Rosalie along to escape danger.
Grabs a man and shoves him to create a roadblock, then vaults over the railing to gain an advantage.
Fights through passengers to board the train quickly, showing quick thinking and decisiveness.
Assures Rosalie he wouldn't hurt her, then shoots Luther after making him show the money.
Laughs as Rosalie screams after shooting Luther.
Is responsible for five deaths related to law enforcement, indicating dangerous and lethal effectiveness.
Successfully evades capture leading to a stolen bus chase and multiple casualties, showing skill and cunning.
Disappears without leaving any trace, making it hard for others to track him.
Described as a 'pure schizo' with 'wires all crossed' and no pattern, implying erratic and unpredictable behavior.
Throws himself off the bed, pushes Sally out of the way to protect her from gunfire.
Fires furiously down the corridor while escaping with the briefcase.
Wakes up quickly, grabs a gun, fires furiously down the corridor, grabs the briefcase, and escapes through the window and fire escape while being pursued.
Stops briefly on the ground after escaping the fire escape, fires a shot at pursuer, then runs again.
Rolls a garbage can to trip Hammond, then holds Hammond hostage with a gun to his ear.
Threatens Cates and Hammond aggressively, using insults and intimidation.
Rolls a garbage can in Hammond's path, causing him to fall and gain the upper hand.
Successfully takes Hammond hostage with a gun to his ear and holds the black bag, showing control of the situation.
Confidently taunts Cates and Hammond, demonstrating psychological control and bravado.
Fails to anticipate Cates' approach and underestimates the cop's willingness to confront him, potentially risking his position.
Refuses to beg for his life despite being shot, runs at Cates screaming and roaring.
Demands the cop give up his gun, showing confidence and control.
Engages in a gunfight but is hit early and loses control of the hostage and weapon.
Despite being shot and in pain, refuses to beg and charges at the opponent, showing determination but poor tactical judgment.
